newsitem.title: GERMANY: Waigel wants "strict adherence" to EMU rules.
newsitem.headline: Waigel wants "strict adherence" to EMU rules.

text.p: Finance Minister Theo Waigel has called for "strict adherence" to the entry qualifications for European economic and monetary union (EMU), a German newspaper said on Saturday.
"Everyone has the same chance to qualify through strict adherence to the convergence criteria," the Bild am Sonntag weekly quoted Waigel as saying in an advance release from Sunday's edition.
Waigel also appeared to back up Bavarian premier Edmund Stoiber's repeated calls for the budget deficit criterion for EMU members to be 3.0 percent of gross domestic product (GDP).
"The Maastricht Treaty names a figure for the deficit criterion and that figure is three. Anyone who now believes 3.2 or 3.3 is sufficient will end up with 3.9 percent," he said.
Stoiber, a member of Waigel's Christian Social Union party, has demanded in recent interviews that 3.0 percent of GDP remain the budget deficit limit.

His comments have provoked anger within Chancellor Helmut Kohl's ruling coalition, where some members favour a less strict interpretation of the criterion to ensure the project starts on schedule on January 1, 1999.
